citation.article-title: Description of Idiomarina insulisalsae sp. nov., isolated from the soil of a sea salt evaporation pond, proposal to transfer the species of the genus Pseudidiomarina to the genus Idiomarina and emended description of the genus Idiomarina

p.s: Emended description of the genus Idiomarina Ivanova et al. [9]
The species of the genus stain Gram-negative, form rod-shaped cells, and most strains are motile by means one polar flagella.
Colonies are non-pigmented or are slightly yellowish-coloured.
The species require NaCl for growth, with a salt range between about 0.5% and 25%; optimum growth in salt-containing medium is variable and ranges from about 1% to 10%.
The optimum pH is around neutral.
Phosphatidylethanolamine, phosphatidylglycerol and diphosphatidylglycerol are the major polar lipids.
Fatty acids are primarily iso- and anteiso-branched; the major fatty acids are C15:0 iso, C17:0 iso, C17:0 anteiso, C17:1 iso ω9c.
Ubiquinone 8 is the major respiratory quinone.
The species of this genus utilize carbohydrates, organic acids and amino acids, among other carbon sources.
The DNA G+C content varies between 45 and 54 mol%.
The species of this genus have been isolated from saline environments.
The type species is Idiomarina abyssalis Ivanova et al. [9].
The type strain is KMM 227 (=ATCC BAA-312T)
